      <title>Genes that influence how long you stay in education uncovered by study</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/11/genes-that-influence-how-long-you-stay-in-education-uncovered-by-study</link>
      <description><p>Discovery of genetic variants which shape number of years spent at school and university, and could pave the way for more personalised teaching </p><p>A haul of genes that influence how long people spend in education has been uncovered by one of the largest studies conducted in the field.</p><p>The international effort by more than 250 scientists found 74 genetic variants that shape the number of years people spend at school and university, with most of the variants involved in brain development, particularly in the womb.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/11/genes-that-influence-how-long-you-stay-in-education-uncovered-by-study">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Dandruff? Soon you'll be reaching for the scalp yoghurt</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/12/scalp-bacteria-could-be-key-to-keeping-dandruff-flakes-at-bay-propionibacterium</link>
      <description><p>Study into the ecosystem of microbes on scalps suggests that nurturing a type of bacteria, called Propionibacterium, could help prevent dandruff</p><p>The next time dandruff dots your shoulders, you might want to reach for yogurt, not shampoo. The latest study into scaly scalps has found that nurturing particular bacteria on the skin could keep the white flakes at bay.</p><p>Researchers in Shanghai took on the dandruff problem with an unprecedented investigation into flaky scalps and the ecosystem of microbes that set up home on the human head, feeding on the lavish menu of dead skin and oily secretions called sebum.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/12/scalp-bacteria-could-be-key-to-keeping-dandruff-flakes-at-bay-propionibacterium">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How the Zika virus causes birth defects</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/neurophilosophy/2016/may/11/zika-virus-birth-defects-first-evidence</link>
      <description><p>New research provides the first direct evidence that Zika virus causes severe birth defects, and explains exactly how it does so</p><p>“I lifted up my T-shirt to check on what I thought had just been a small heat rash,” <a href="https://www.buzzfeed.com/alimwatkins/i-went-to-mexico-and-all-i-got-was-this-stupid-zika-virus?utm_term=.st4VwQw4m#.eyM8kbkVa">writes</a> BuzzFeed correspondent Ali Watkins. “It had shown up along the right of my back, extending out from a handful of mosquito bites I had picked up… it had seemed relatively tame [but] now, it was inching across the front of my stomach and down my legs... Meanwhile, my right eye was inflamed and bright red, almost akin to a busted blood vessel.”</p><p>Watkins is describing the symptoms of a Zika virus infection that she contracted on a recent trip to Mexico. For many people, infection with this mosquito-borne virus causes an illness with symptoms just like those experienced by Watkins: fever, skin rash, joint pain and conjunctivitis. For others, these symptoms are so mild that they go completely unnoticed. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/neurophilosophy/2016/may/11/zika-virus-birth-defects-first-evidence">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/zika-virus">Zika virus</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/science/science">Science</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/science/neuroscience">Neuroscience</category>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 17:00:04 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/science/neurophilosophy/2016/may/11/zika-virus-birth-defects-first-evidence</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/7ebc099584b3cdd2f1411d102239157a2485c5d9/0_38_3500_2100/3500.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=22ea93ef0cf77b1b4f5791c772086a77">

      </media:content>
      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/7ebc099584b3cdd2f1411d102239157a2485c5d9/0_38_3500_2100/3500.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=a066e2361869209107222a891e09066d">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Nacho Doce/Reuters</media:credit>
      </media:content>

    <item>
      <title>Ancient Egyptian coffin found to hold youngest known mummified foetus</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/11/ancient-egyptian-coffin-found-to-hold-youngest-known-mummified-foetus</link>
      <description><p>Scanning reveals coffin from 600BC, originally though by curators to contain preserved organs, holds a foetus of no more than 18 weeks gestation</p><p>A miniature coffin from ancient Egypt that was thought to contain an individual’s preserved organs has been found to hold the youngest known mummified human foetus to be embalmed and buried by the civilisation.</p><p>The 44cm-long coffin fell into the hands of the Fitzwilliam Museum in Cambridge in 1907, after it was excavated from Giza in Egypt the same year. And while the cedar wood coffin from 600BC had deteriorated, the small, black bundle inside remained intact.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/11/ancient-egyptian-coffin-found-to-hold-youngest-known-mummified-foetus">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>'Triumph or disaster?': MPs question Boaty McBoatface research council chief</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/10/triumph-or-disaster-mps-question-boaty-mcboatface-research-council-chief</link>
      <description><p>Commons committee question Natural Environment Research Council head over ship-naming competition as part of inquiry into science communication</p><p>No sooner had MPs taken their seats than it began. “Will the minister ask you to walk the plank?” asked Nicola Blackwood, chair of the Commons science and technology committee. Her question was directed at Duncan Wingham, head of the Natural Environment Research Council (NERC), who had been <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/05/boaty-mcboatface-mps-to-quiz-nerc-head-over-ship-naming-competition">summoned to Westminster</a> to answer questions on the <a href="https://nameourship.nerc.ac.uk/?id=jqNWiSui">Boaty McBoatface</a> episode.</p><p>The committee had long planned an <a href="http://www.parliament.uk/business/committees/committees-a-z/commons-select/science-and-technology-committee/">inquiry into science communication</a>, and NERC’s <a href="https://nameourship.nerc.ac.uk/">Name Our Ship competition</a> - won with <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/mar/20/eccentric-choices-surface-in-quest-to-name-polar-research-vessel">massive public support</a> by Boaty McBoatface, only for the name to be vetoed by Science minister Jo Johnson in favour of the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/06/boaty-mcboatface-ship-to-be-called-rrs-sir-david-attenborough">RRS Sir David Attenborough</a> - was a natural place to start. Was it a PR triumph or a PR disaster? The MPs wanted to know.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/10/triumph-or-disaster-mps-question-boaty-mcboatface-research-council-chief">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/science/science">Science</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/poles">Polar regions</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/houseofcommons">House of Commons</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/environment">Environment</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/politics">Politics</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/uk/uk">UK news</category>
      <pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 17:46:34 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/10/triumph-or-disaster-mps-question-boaty-mcboatface-research-council-chief</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/a533f048cfea260871728c6bd39e4d3b9d03126d/333_0_3090_1855/3090.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=42fe565ef5ba8880fd8730da6a7b8dbd">

      <title>Thunderbolts and time travel: my journey to the cosmic heart of land art</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/may/11/deserts-and-dynamite-my-journey-to-the-cosmic-heart-of-land-art</link>
      <description><p>As new film Troublemakers explores the extremes of land art, from lightning fields to satanic jetties, Alex Needham braves rattlesnakes to visit a desert observatory that lets you travel 26,000 years in time</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/11/troublemakers-the-story-of-land-art-review-spiral-jetty-james-crumb-documentary">Troublemakers: The Story of Land Art review – sculptors who shaped the American wilderness</a> </p><p>Somewhere in the deserts of New Mexico, a nail is embedded into a type of flat-topped mountain known as a mesa. The positioning of this nail, shielded from the elements by a tin can, took days of trial and error, with astronomical measurements provided by the US Naval Observatory and the help of a surveyor. Finally, the correct spot was located: exactly in alignment with the axis of the Earth from the south pole to the north.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/may/11/deserts-and-dynamite-my-journey-to-the-cosmic-heart-of-land-art">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Ewa Wybacz, 36, is mother of first baby born in UK from trial of more precise embryo screening technique</p><p>A woman who was told she would never have children has given birth to a baby boy after doctors used a new DNA procedure to screen her embryos.</p><p>Ewa Wybacz, 36, gave birth to her son, Biagio Russu, in January despite a history of medical problems that had led her to believe she would never conceive.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/09/woman-told-she-could-not-have-children-has-baby-with-dna-method">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Microsculpture: hidden beauty of the bugs beneath our feet</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/08/microsculpture-exhibition-insects-photography-levon-biss</link>
      <description>When photographer Levon Biss turned his lens on the insects his son was collecting in the garden, it opened up a miniature world in which art meets science to dazzling effect<p>Two years ago, exhausted by the frantic pressures of commercial portraiture, photographer <a href="http://www.levonbiss.com/" title="">Levon Biss</a> was searching for a way to relax. His son Sebastian, then six, found the answer in their back garden. “My boy likes insects,” says Biss. “He’s always in the garden trying to find them and play with them. I started shooting insects he’d caught, so that he could see them clearly and be proud of finding them.” Making detailed portraits of insect specimens proved to be the perfect antidote to the trigger-happy, “disposable” photography that Biss feels is the current fashion. “I wanted a project that made me think, that was a challenge,” he says, and he gradually developed a technique so specialised and laborious, only a photographer of extreme patience and dedication could sustain it.</p><p>First, the pinned insect is mounted on an adapted microscope-stand in front of a camera with a macro lens. Biss then divides the insect into 30 sections, to be photographed separately at close range. “When you get to this magnification,” he explains, “the depth of field is so shallow, there’s only a minute plane of focus.” To render, for instance, a whole wing-casing in focus, it must be photographed around 750 times, with each photo taken 10 microns apart. Those 750 images are then painstakingly compiled into a composite, using a variety of sophisticated software.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/08/microsculpture-exhibition-insects-photography-levon-biss">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Scientists are speaking up in debates over Brexit. So why is big business silent?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/political-science/2016/may/12/scientists-are-speaking-up-in-debates-over-brexit-so-why-is-big-business-silent</link>
      <description><p>Academics are queuing up to make the case for staying in the EU. But almost all the larger R&amp;D-intensive companies have kept their heads down. Why?</p><p>Science is a vital part of the UK’s relationship with the rest of Europe. <a href="https://royalsociety.org/news/2015/12/UK%20research%20and%20EU/">Some eighteen per cent of EU funding returned to the UK is for research</a>. The UK is a net contributor to the EU across the board, but a net beneficiary in science. Businesses are responsible for around two-thirds of research and development (R&amp;D) investment in the UK, with firms headquartered overseas making up half of that figure – by far the highest proportion among G7 countries. </p><p>Against that background, I expected business to have plenty to say during the recent inquiry into <a href="http://www.parliament.uk/business/committees/committees-a-z/lords-select/science-and-technology-committee/news-parliament-2015/eu-membership-report-published/">‘EU membership and UK science’ by the House of Lords Committee on Science and Technology</a>, for which I was the specialist advisor. Amidst lively exchanges between <a href="https://twitter.com/sciencebritain">pro-leave</a> and <a href="http://scientistsforeu.uk/">pro-remain</a> campaign groups, the House of Lords conducted a calm analysis of the evidence on the scientific dimensions of the EU debate. Around eighty written submissions and thirty expert witnesses set out arguments and analysis. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/political-science/2016/may/12/scientists-are-speaking-up-in-debates-over-brexit-so-why-is-big-business-silent">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>To confront 21st century challenges, science must rethink its reward system</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/political-science/2016/may/12/to-confront-21st-century-challenges-science-needs-to-rethink-its-reward-system</link>
      <description><p>One of Science in Transition’s founders describes how his experience as a young HIV/AIDS researcher convinced him that science needs to change</p><p>HIV/AIDS research in the early 1980s was a new and exciting field of science. I had started working as a biomedical researcher in Amsterdam, a city with a large and visible gay community. The new disease was a threat to public health and was highly contagious. It was transmitted by sexual contact and in the developed world affected young healthy gay men and recipients of blood and blood products. It took some time to realise that a truly immense and devastating epidemic was going on in sub-Saharan Africa affecting men, women and children. </p><p>This disease attracted bright scientific minds all over the world, working feverishly to understand the origin and biology of the virus. We wanted to know how the virus moved through the population, entered and killed immune cells and how to counteract it. AIDS patients were dying in the hospitals and we were working as fast as we could towards better therapies for HIV-positive patients.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/political-science/2016/may/12/to-confront-21st-century-challenges-science-needs-to-rethink-its-reward-system">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Science hasn't 'proved' that women go for bad boys | Girl On The Net</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/brain-flapping/2016/may/12/science-hasnt-proved-that-women-go-for-bad-boys</link>
      <description><p>Some argue that the claim that ‘women love bad boys’ is scientifically proven. However, this isn’t the case</p><p>“Women always go for the bad boys.” “Nice guys finish last.” “Treat ‘em mean, keep ‘em keen.”</p><p>There are so many variations on the idea that women brush off advances from lovely men and instead deliberately chase guys who are tall, dark and horrible. If it’s true, why is the crime rate not significantly higher, as straight guys compete with each other to look “badder” than their friends? In fact what do we mean by “bad” anyway? Are we talking bank robbers, or just your mate Clive who once dumped a girl via text? </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/brain-flapping/2016/may/12/science-hasnt-proved-that-women-go-for-bad-boys">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>SATs: the dangerous exam that's frying our children's brains | Dean Burnett</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/brain-flapping/2016/may/10/sats-the-dangerous-exam-thats-frying-our-childrens-brains</link>
      <description><p>Often new technology or development is condemned as being “damaging to children”. Why not apply that approach to the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/education/2016/may/10/sats-tests-go-ahead-despite-leak-education-department">disastrous government SATs</a>?</p><p>You may have noticed that it’s very common, particularly in the more right-wing leaning media, to suggest that something is bad because it’s potentially harmful to children, particularly their brains. <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/brain-flapping/2013/sep/20/video-games-cause-violence-claims-cause-violence">Video games</a>, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/head-quarters/2015/feb/02/no-research-does-not-say-that-ipads-and-smartphones-may-damage-toddlers-brains">smartphones and tablets</a>, <a href="http://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/news/10619007/Children-using-social-networks-underage-exposes-them-to-danger.html">Facebook</a>, the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/aug/15/online-safety-internet-sexting-cyberbullying-children">internet as a whole</a>, <a href="http://www.wsj.com/articles/pediatricians-rethink-screen-time-policy-for-children-1444671636">screens in general</a>, <a href="http://rekordeast.co.za/64679/9-reasons-to-keep-your-kids-away-from-fizzy-drinks/">fizzy drinks</a>, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/brain-flapping/2013/jan/04/vaccination-childrens-tv-cbeebies-complaint">vaccines</a>, and who knows what else. All of these have been condemned by many on the grounds that they have the potential to harm children’s brains.</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/susan-greenfield">Susan Greenfield</a>, for example, has made some alarming (and, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/brain-flapping/2013/apr/09/susan-greenfield-article-how-to-guide">some would say</a>, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/head-quarters/2015/aug/13/susan-greenfield-bmj-editorial-digital-technology-video-games-need-less-shock-and-more-substance">evidence-light</a>) claims about the dangers posed by new technology on <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/brain-flapping/2012/sep/10/children-brains-damage-susan-greenfield">the delicate, fragile minds of children</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/brain-flapping/2016/may/10/sats-the-dangerous-exam-thats-frying-our-childrens-brains">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>What has science communication ever done for us?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/political-science/2016/may/10/what-has-science-communication-ever-done-for-us</link>
      <description><p>As a parliamentary inquiry into science and the public begins, I’d argue there’s been a revolution in the way researchers think about science and engagement</p><p>“What have the Romans ever done for us?” John Cleese’s famous question from Monty Python’s <a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0079470/">Life of Brian</a> has been in my thoughts over the past couple of weeks. Back came the answer, “The aqueduct.” “Oh, yeah, yeah. They did give us that.” “And there’s sanitation...” You get the picture.</p><p>I’ve been recalling lines from Monty Python thanks to the <a href="http://www.parliament.uk/business/committees/committees-a-z/commons-select/science-and-technology-committee/">House of Commons select committee on science and technology</a>, which today begins a round of public hearings for its latest <a href="http://www.parliament.uk/business/committees/committees-a-z/commons-select/science-and-technology-committee/inquiries/parliament-2015/science-communication-inquiry-15-16/">inquiry</a> into science communication. In essence, the committee is asking: “What has science communication ever done for us?”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/political-science/2016/may/10/what-has-science-communication-ever-done-for-us">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>The results from <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/09/can-you-solve-it-are-you-smarter-than-a-british-11-year-old">this morning’s maths challenge</a>. Stand by to compare your marks!</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/09/can-you-solve-it-are-you-smarter-than-a-british-11-year-old">Earlier today</a> I set you ten questions from the <a href="https://www.ukmt.org.uk/">UK Mathematics Trust</a>’s Junior Maths Challenge, which was sat by 300,000 11-13 year olds the week before last.</p><p>Here are the questions, answers and explanations. I have also included the percentage of children who got it right and the percentage of Guardian readers who did.     <item>
      <title>Before the Transit of Mercury: forgotten forerunners of an astronomical revolution | Karl Galle</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/the-h-word/2016/may/09/transit-of-mercury-forgotten-astronomical-revolution</link>
      <description><p>A manuscript note in the Royal Society Library hints at an observing program that would eventually transform our ability to predict the motions of the planets<strong>.</strong></p><p>“Today I saw Mercury.” This terse remark scrawled inside a 16th-century almanac could reflect <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/across-the-universe/2016/may/06/how-to-see-mercury-transit-the-sun-on-9-may">anyone watching today’s</a> <a href="http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2016/2016-transit-mercury/">transit of Mercury</a> across the Sun. The winding path this observation took after it was recorded, however, traces a century-long story leading through the transformation of both our understanding of the cosmos and the practice of astronomy itself.</p><p> Mercury’s observer in this case was <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willibald_Pirckheimer">Willibald Pirckheimer</a>, a German humanist who made diary notes in a set of astronomical tables by <a href="http://www-groups.dcs.st-and.ac.uk/history/Biographies/Regiomontanus.html">Johannes Regiomontanus</a>, which are now preserved in the <a href="https://royalsociety.org/collections/">Royal Society Library</a>. Pirckheimer almost certainly wasn’t alone, as the same Mercury sighting (early in the evening of 18 March 1504) was recorded in more detail by his friend Bernhard Walther, who had inherited Regiomontanus’ observation program and copious manuscripts. Perhaps it was solely an observing session, or perhaps it preceded one of the festive banquets Nuremberg’s humanists were known for. We may not know the evening’s full itinerary, but it’s a reminder that science was <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/08/transit-of-mercury-share-your-images-and-stories">rarely a solo activity</a> even back then.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/the-h-word/2016/may/09/transit-of-mercury-forgotten-astronomical-revolution">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/science/science">Science</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/science/history-science">History of science</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/science/astronomy">Astronomy</category>
      <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 07:30:08 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/science/the-h-word/2016/may/09/transit-of-mercury-forgotten-astronomical-revolution</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/70ae80ca67babd3eb7598ea0b6ce2bb3cec64b4b/7_0_2379_1428/2379.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=bb7e0a23f94ca8fe4863dd8ad86d2a91">

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/google-images-as-good-as-fieldwork-for-studying-animal-colour</link>
      <description><p>Study of different colours in black bears, barn owls, black sparrowhawks and crows finds online images can substitute for costly fieldwork</p><p>Studying photographs of animals posted online by the general public has proven to be as valuable as traditional fieldwork in research on the locations of species that have evolved with different colours. </p><p>Colour polymorphism - the occurrence of two or more colour types in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population">population</a> of a species - has long fascinated biologists.       <description><p>Staff given two weeks to explain why their jobs should be saved, followed by a two-month process in which management tries to find them another role</p><p>Climate scientists at the CSIRO who are earmarked for redundancy will learn their fate this week.</p><p>Staff in the organisation’s oceans and atmosphere business unit began being told of their “potential” redundancies on Tuesday, and the process was expected to continue until Thursday.       <title>Oldest known axe discovered in Australia, claim researchers</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/10/oldest-known-axe-discovered-in-australia-claim-researchers</link>
      <description><p>Small fragment found in cave believed to date from a tool created up to 49,000 years ago</p><p>It is about the size of a thumbnail and might look like any old piece of rock, but scientists say it is a fragment of the oldest axe ever discovered, created up to 49,000 years ago.</p><p>Found in Australia, it further undermines ideas that Europe was the birthplace of technology, revealing people developed complex tools not long after they set foot in Australia.<br tabindex="-1"></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/10/oldest-known-axe-discovered-in-australia-claim-researchers">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>More than 1,200 new planets discovered through Nasa's Kepler space telescope</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/10/new-planets-discovered-nasa-kepler-space-telescope</link>
      <description><p>More than doubling the number of confirmed planets orbiting alien stars, astronomers said that the discovery is a step toward finding Earth-like planets<br></p><p>Nasa added more than 1,200 new planets to the known galaxy on Tuesday, more than doubling the number of confirmed planets orbiting alien stars.<br></p><p>Revealing data from the Kepler space telescope, the astronomers said that the discovery is a step toward finding Earth-like planets. “This gives us hope that somewhere out there, around a star much like ours, we can eventually discover another Earth,” said Ellen Stofan, Nasa’s chief scientist.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/10/new-planets-discovered-nasa-kepler-space-telescope">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Probiotic goods a 'waste of money' for healthy adults, research suggests</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/10/probiotic-goods-a-waste-of-money-for-healthy-adults-research-suggests</link>
      <description><p>University of Copenhagen study finds no evidence that so-called friendly bacteria change the composition of faecal bacteria</p><p>Fans of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2014/nov/30/probiotics-myth-or-miracle-prebiotics">probiotic drinks and foods</a> may be wasting their money, according to a review of current research into the supplements that suggests they may be of no benefit to healthy adults.</p><p>A Danish team looked at the results of seven trials of the products – often sold as milk-based drinks, biscuits, sachets, or capsules – and found no evidence they changed the composition of faecal bacteria in healthy adults.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/10/probiotic-goods-a-waste-of-money-for-healthy-adults-research-suggests">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Researchers say there were 33,000 avoidable deaths in 10 years because patients did not receive proven treatments</p><p>Thousands of people a year are dying unnecessarily after a heart attack because NHS follow-up care is so poor, a study says.<br tabindex="-1"></p><p>Six in seven of the 40,000 heart attack patients a year miss out on at least one of the treatments that have been proven to reduce their risk of having another one and dying, it found. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/10/heart-attacks-kill-thousands-each-year-because-of-poor-nhs-after-care-study-says">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>One in five of world's plant species at risk of extinction</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/10/one-in-five-of-worlds-plant-species-at-risk-of-extinction</link>
      <description><p>Global report highlights threat to food security and medicine supplies but also reveals 2,000 new species are discovered each year</p><p>One in five of the world’s plant species is threatened with extinction, according to the first global assessment of flora, putting supplies of food and medicines at risk.</p><p>But the report also found that 2,000 new species of plant are discovered every year, raising hopes of new sources of food that are resilient to disease and climate change. New finds in 2015 included a giant insect-eating plant first spotted on Facebook and a 100-tonne tree hidden in an African forest.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/10/one-in-five-of-worlds-plant-species-at-risk-of-extinction">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Brexit ‘will put UK access to cutting-edge medicines at risk’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/07/brexit-uk-medicines-cameron-eu-referendum</link>
      <description>Letter from top drugs companies offers boost to David Cameron and remain campaign in EU referendum<p>British people benefit at the earliest opportunity from the best medicines produced by “cutting-edge” research because the UK is part of the EU, 93 business leaders and organisations from the life-sciences industry say.</p><p>The group, which includes executives from the top trio of companies – GlaxoSmithKline, AstraZeneca and Pfizer – says EU funding for research and Europe-wide regulations help produce new, more effective drugs more quickly.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/07/brexit-uk-medicines-cameron-eu-referendum">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/eu-referendum">EU referendum</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/uk/uk">UK news</category>

    <item>
      <title>Atopodentatus was a hammerheaded herbivore, new fossil find shows</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/06/atopodentatus-was-a-hammerheaded-herbivore-new-fossil-find-shows</link>
      <description><p>Find changes previous view of <em>Atopodentatus unicus</em>, revealing the 244-million-year-old creature to be the earliest known plant-eating marine reptile </p><p>An ancient creature with a skull the shape of a vacuum attachment could have been one of the first plant-eating marine reptiles, researchers say.</p><p>Dug up in Luoping County in the Yunnan province of China, the newly discovered fossils of the sea-dwelling creature <em>Atopodentatus unicus, </em>thought to have lived around 244 million years ago,<em> </em>suggest it had a “hammerhead” skull, with two very different sets of teeth that allowed it to feed on underwater plant matter. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/06/atopodentatus-was-a-hammerheaded-herbivore-new-fossil-find-shows">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Russia launches first rocket from new spaceport</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/12/spacewatch-russia-launches-new-spaceport</link>
      <description><p>Russia has launched the first rocket from its new spaceport. Although not yet finished, the <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2016/apr/28/putin-watches-first-rocket-launch-from-new-vosochny-cosmodrome-video">Vostochny cosmodrome</a> has cost £2bn and taken five years to build so far. When completed in the 2020s, it will launch cosmonauts and <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/09/russia-launches-first-space-rocket-soviet-era">Russia’s new Angara rocket</a>, which could eventually take people to the moon.</p><p>The spaceport became operational on 28 April when a <a draggable="true" href="http://spaceflight101.com/spacerockets/soyuz-2-1v/">Soyuz-2.1 rocket</a> lifted off carrying three satellites into orbit. Vladimir Putin attended the launch and had words of both congratulation and warning.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/12/spacewatch-russia-launches-new-spaceport">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sir Denys Wilkinson obituary</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/09/sir-denys-wilkinson-obituary</link>
      <description>Physicist and expert on the electromagnetic properties of nuclear isotopes<p>In 1943, the physicist Sir Denys Wilkinson, who has died aged 93, gained his first degree, and was immediately drawn into second world war service, initially on radar. From there he went on to nuclear physics, as a member of the British nuclear reactor team relocated from Cambridge to Canada until 1946 to facilitate collaboration with the US in developing nuclear weapons.</p><p>Though this was the first step in a career that saw Wilkinson become a professor at Oxford University (1957-76) and vice-chancellor of Sussex (1976-89), it almost took a quite different direction. In Canada, Wilkinson’s job was to monitor neutrons in the reactor. This proved nearly fatal, as he got radiation sickness, his white blood count fell, and he was given six months to live. Having recovered, and back in Cambridge, for a time afterwards it looked as if he probably would not be able to go back to nuclear physics. He became interested in a mystery of bird migration, and applied to the problem analysis techniques that he had learned from nuclear physics to solving it.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/09/sir-denys-wilkinson-obituary">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>'The heavens in motion': astronomers and public marvel at Mercury transit</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/09/the-heavens-in-motion-astronomers-and-public-marvel-at-mercury-transit</link>
      <description><p>As the solar system’s smallest planet passes the face of the sun, thousands from across the world <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/live/2016/may/09/transit-of-mercury-2016-follow-todays-celestial-event-live">gather to gaze at the skies</a></p><p>For once the weather forecasters were wrong about bad news.</p><p>The entire staff of the Royal Observatory at Greenwich, all the passionate amateur astronomers of the Flamsteed Society, and many anxious members of the public, spent the weekend obsessively refreshing the Met Office weather forecast app – but the threat never changed, the skies over London would have 100% cloud cover, and the best chance of observing the transit of Mercury before 2049 would be lost.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/09/the-heavens-in-motion-astronomers-and-public-marvel-at-mercury-transit">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Transit of Mercury: what you need to know and how to watch it</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/08/starwatch-transit-mercury-9-may</link>
      <description><p>The smallest planet passes the face of the sun today. Here’s what you need to know and how you can watch it safely. </p><p>The transit of Mercury across the face of the Sun on Monday 9 May is the first for the planet since 2006 and the first to be visible from Britain since 2003. Our next occurs in 2019, but we must wait until 2049 for a more favourable one than this.</p><p>We might think that the little innermost planet would cross in front of the Sun every 116 days or so, every time it swings around the near side of its orbit of the Sun. However, that orbit is tilted at 7° to that of the Earth, so Mercury usually sweeps unseen above or below the Sun when it is closest, at its so-called inferior conjunction. The next most inclined orbit is that of Venus at 3.4°.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/08/starwatch-transit-mercury-9-may">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Lilly Dubowitz obituary</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/08/lilly-dubowitz-obituary</link>
      <description>Paediatrician, neurologist and author whose work revolutionised the assessment of newborn babies<p>In the early 1970s, a husband and wife team developed two novel clinical tests that revolutionised the way newborn infants are assessed in clinical and research practice around the world. One was for determining gestational age; the other for the systematic neurological examination of the newborn. The scientists were Victor and Lilly Dubowitz. Lilly, who has died aged 85, was a leading figure in the field of neonatology, and her pioneering work spanning more than 40 years is internationally recognised. The Dubowitz score and the Dubowitz neonatal examination have been used by generations of neonatologists and paediatric neurologists.</p><p>The assessment of gestational age in the newborn infant, developed with Victor and published in 1970, was immediately adopted worldwide as a way of distinguishing small babies who were mature but malnourished from those who were premature and of appropriate small size. It measured some neurological signs, such as the infant’s ability to flex and extend its joints and limbs, and also some superficial signs, examining the skin, eyes, ears, genitals and other physical characteristics for signs of maturity. From these, after the examiner had matched the infant’s responses with the options on an illustrative chart, came the Dubowitz score. The beauty of the test was that it was simple and easily recorded through clinical observation. <strong> </strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/08/lilly-dubowitz-obituary">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Charles Thomas obituary</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/08/charles-thomas-obituary</link>
      <description>Archaeologist with a particular passion for the history of his native Cornwall<p>Charles Thomas, who has died aged 87, was an outstanding scholar of early Britain, with an international reputation. He researched and published widely about Cornwall, its local history, its archaeology and religion, its language, dialect, customs, folklore and humour, its art and artists, its military history and its relationship with other Celtic nations. He was also a nonconformist in every sense: a committed Methodist and a founding member of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk/2012/jan/26/cornish-party-mebyon-kernow-future" title="">Mebyon Kernow</a>, the Cornish nationalist party.</p><p>I first met Charles in July 1955, when I was mistakenly the first volunteer to arrive on an archaeological excavation. Charles seized the moment, gave me a yard-broom, peremptorily told me to clean up one of the dilapidated Nissen huts in which we were to live – and disappeared. I later appreciated that this was typical Thomasian behaviour, and why some found him abrupt and even arrogant; in fact he was shy. Above all, he was kind and a marvellous encourager, especially in the field.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/08/charles-thomas-obituary">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sir Harry Kroto obituary</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/05/sir-harry-kroto-obituary</link>
      <description>Chemist who won the Nobel prize for his role in discovering buckminsterfullerenes, also known as ‘buckyballs’<p>Sir Harry Kroto, who has died aged 76, was awarded the Nobel prize in chemistry in 1996 for his part in the discovery of buckminsterfullerenes, also known as “buckyballs” – carbon atoms found in the form of a ball. In 1985 Harry, then professor of chemistry at the University of Sussex, had teamed up with <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2005/nov/09/highereducation.education">Rick Smalley</a> and <a href="https://chemistry.rice.edu/FacultyDetail.aspx?RiceID=589">Robert Curl</a>, both professors of chemistry at Rice University, in Houston, Texas, to laser-vaporise carbon in laboratory experiments designed to simulate the chemistry of stars and interstellar space. Their experiments appeared to indicate that they had made an unexpected molecular species comprising 60 carbon atoms. This was amazing. Carbon had long been known to exist as diamond or graphite, but carbon as a small molecule required completely new thinking.</p><p>This was where Harry drew on his artistic side and a knowledge of graphic design: he proposed that C<sub>60</sub> was made up of a mixture of pentagons and hexagons, a structure known in ancient times, and now ubiquitous in footballs and in the work of the US architect and inventor <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/03/obituaries/r-buckminster-fuller-futurist-inventor-dies-at-87.html?pagewanted=all">Buckminster Fuller</a>. But at first nobody could prove it, and many were openly sceptical.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/05/sir-harry-kroto-obituary">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/1f512781f98c0186289f14ee0e0dd23dc1d261d5/0_241_5013_3008/5013.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=45cee792374cb4e63e2adcf346bce1db">

      <title>Barbara Knowles obituary</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/03/barbara-knowles-obituary</link>
      <description><p>My sister, Barbara Knowles, who has died aged 55, was an enthusiastic biologist, a scientific adviser to the <a href="https://www.rsb.org.uk/membership" title="">Royal Society of Biology</a> (RSB) and a champion of meadow ecology and sustainable development projects, especially in Transylvania.</p><p>She worked in the Pogány-havas region of the eastern Carpathians with local volunteers and experts to record and protect valuable flora and fauna. She established the <a href="http://www.treasuresoftransylvania.org/" title="">Barbara Knowles Fund</a> and supported activities working with schoolchildren, academics and policymakers.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/03/barbara-knowles-obituary">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How to bump an asteroid off course</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/01/how-bump-asteroid-off-course</link>
      <description><p>Roughly every other week a one-metre-wide asteroid impacts on Earth’s atmosphere and creates a spectacular fireball. Meanwhile, every few decades a lump of rock the size of a double-decker bus comes our way, creating a small crater on the ground like the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2013/nov/06/chelyabinsk-meteor-russia">Russian Chelyabinsk event</a> on 15 February 2013. </p><p>Asteroids that cause significant damage (football-field-sized rocks) slam into us every 5,000 years or so, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2015/mar/24/evidence-of-largest-asteroid-impact-zone-on-earth-found-in-australian-outback">and the real biggies</a> – capable of causing global disaster – arrive every few million years.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/01/how-bump-asteroid-off-course">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Letter: Sir David MacKay obituary</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/01/letter-sir-david-mackay-obituary</link>
      <description><p><strong> </strong>In the late 1980s I was a scientist at the Royal Signals and Radar Establishment in Malvern. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/18/sir-david-mackay-obituary" title="">David MacKay</a> was placed with our team as our summer student for two months’ work experience. It rapidly became clear that not only did he fit well into our small thermal imaging research team, but he was able to complete the tasks we allocated to him in about half the time we would normally expect for a student.</p><p>In his final week we ran out of jobs, so we suggested he could do his own little project. He presented us with an astrolabe made from cardboard and odds and ends found round the lab, with the appropriate azimuth and altitude circles for Malvern plotted on plastic transparencies using our lab plotter. When he left to go back to his second undergraduate year, we were sure he was heading for great things.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/01/letter-sir-david-mackay-obituary">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description>Any woman should be able to make good decisions about her body – and if Daljinder Kaur is strong enough to fulfil her parenting dream perhaps we should lay off<p>The birth of Armaan Singh Gill, a <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/10/indian-woman-in-her-70s-gives-birth-to-healthy-baby-boy" title="">2kg boy, to Daljinder Kaur</a> was announced by Indian and international media this week. Though she has no birth certificate, Kaur, estimated to be 72, is thought to be the world’s oldest mother. Armaan was her first child.     <item>
      <title>Dieting can backfire – but don’t blame it on greed and laziness | Thomas Barber</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/10/obesity-greed-laziness-overweight-people-metabolism-weight-loss</link>
      <description>Overweight people can easily pile the pounds back on after a diet, betrayed by a metabolism that’s both under-evolved and damaged by weight loss<p>Obesity is one of the biggest threats to the health of our species. Over the past 40 years there has been a remarkable change to human bodies globally. According to the World Health Organisation, most adults living <a href="http://www.healthdata.org/news-release/vast-majority-american-adults-are-overweight-or-obese-and-weight-growing-problem-among" title="">in the US</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/may/29/uk-western-europe-obesity-study" title="">Europe</a> are either overweight or obese.</p><p>Yet worryingly for those of us seeking to tackle this problem, a recent study in the New York Times of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/may/29/uk-western-europe-obesity-study" title="">contestants who lost weight on the TV show The Biggest Loser</a> showed that the formerly obese have lower resting metabolic rates than others of a similar weight – making it all the easier for them to pile back on the weight. They could eat the same as someone else of the same weight, but pile on the pounds regardless.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/10/obesity-greed-laziness-overweight-people-metabolism-weight-loss">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Plants are our lifeline – but we’re letting them die | Michael McCarthy</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/10/plants-wild-plant-species-kew</link>
      <description><p>Human existence is utterly dependent on wild plant species we’ve shamefully neglected. Now Kew has become a global voice for plants</p><p>There seem to have been no national ceremonies to mark the end of botany. A discipline that had flourished in our universities for centuries – the first Oxford professor of botany, <a href="http://botany.edwardworthlibrary.ie/robert-morison/">Robert Morison</a>, was awarded his chair in 1669 – slipped away quietly into oblivion in 2013, with the graduation of the last students on the last undergraduate botany course, at Bristol. You can’t do a botany degree in Britain any more. A once familiar element of life has simply disappeared, quite unremarked upon. Like the <a href="http://freakonomics.com/podcast/where-have-all-the-hitchhikers-gone-a-new-freakonomics-radio-podcast/">disappearance of hitchhiking</a>, you might say.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/10/one-in-five-of-worlds-plant-species-at-risk-of-extinction">One in five of world's plant species at risk of extinction</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/10/plants-wild-plant-species-kew">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Imagine if you could delete bad memories. Well, you can | Ed Cooke</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/09/delete-bad-memories-forget</link>
      <description><p>A new study shows that it’s possible to deliberately forget things. It turns out that’s a surprisingly useful life skill</p><p>A mental adventure familiar to most students is that of cramming one’s mind with knowledge in the run up to an exam. Once the exam is done, we gleefully evacuate our brain of all this hard-won learning that’s no longer needed. Within days, we can barely remember the subject matter, let alone the details. At such moments, it’s as if we’ve forgotten on purpose. </p><p>It might then come as a surprise to learn that until recently, there was little scientific evidence that people could have any deliberate influence on their rates of forgetting. But in the last few years, a small family of experimental techniques have showed that, under the right conditions, we can in fact deliberately forget things. The effects are subtle, but nonetheless suggestive: being able to forget at will would, after all, be a killer life skill. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/09/delete-bad-memories-forget">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Guardian view on artificial intelligence: look out, it’s ahead of you | Editorial</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/08/the-guardian-view-on-artificial-intelligence-look-out-its-ahead-of-you</link>
      <description>There is a tendency to see intelligence where it does not exist. But it is just as wrong to fail to see where it is emerging<p>Google artificial intelligence project <a href="https://deepmind.com/health" title="">DeepMind</a> is building software to trawl through <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/feb/24/smartphone-apps-google-deepmind-nhs-hospitals" title="">millions of patient records</a> from three NHS hospitals to detect early signs of kidney disease. The project raises deep questions not only about data protection but about the ethics of artificial intelligence. But these are not the obvious questions about the ethics of autonomous, intelligent computers.</p><p>Computer programs can now do some things that it once seemed only human beings could do, such as playing an excellent <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/mar/12/alphago-beats-lee-sedol-in-third-consecutive-go-game" title="">game of Go</a>. But even the smartest computer cannot make ethical choices, because it has no purpose of its own in life. The program that plays Go cannot decide that it also wants a driving licence like its cousin, the program that drives Google’s cars.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/08/the-guardian-view-on-artificial-intelligence-look-out-its-ahead-of-you">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description>Researchers want to reassess the 14-day limit, but this will happen only after a sensitive and wide-ranging ethical discussion<p>Scientists have <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/04/scientists-break-record-for-keeping-lab-grown-human-embryos-alive" title="">maintained the life of human embryos outside the womb for 13 days</a>. Whatever. It’s a big deal.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/06/extend-14-day-limit-embryo-research">It’s time to extend the 14-day limit for embryo research | John Harris</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/08/embryo-rule-science">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Gut bacteria regulate nerve fibre insulation</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/neurophilosophy/2016/apr/05/gut-bacteria-brain-myelin</link>
      <description><p>Research suggests that gut bacteria may directly affect brain structure and function, offering new ways to treat multiple sclerosis and psychiatric conditions </p><p>Far from being silent partners that merely help to digest food, the bacteria in your gut may also be exerting <a href="https://neurophilosophy.files.wordpress.com/2013/04/microbes-on-your-mind.pdf">subtle influences on your thoughts</a>, moods, and behaviour. And according to <a href="http://www.nature.com/tp/journal/v6/n4/full/tp201642a.html">a new study</a> from researchers at University College Cork, your gut microbes might affect the structure and function of the brain in a more direct way, by regulating myelination, the process by which nerve fibres are insulated so that they can conduct impulses properly.</p><p>The surprising new findings, published today in the journal <em>Translational Psychiatry</em>, provide what is perhaps the strongest evidence yet that gut bacteria can have a direct physical effect on the brain, and suggest that it may one day be possible to treat debilitating demyelinating diseases such as multiple sclerosis, and even psychiatric disorders, by altering the composition of the gut’s microbial menagerie in some way or another.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/neurophilosophy/2016/apr/05/gut-bacteria-brain-myelin">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/science/science">Science</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/science/neuroscience">Neuroscience</category>

    <item>
      <title>Neuroscientists create ‘atlas’ showing how words are organised in the brain</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/apr/27/brain-atlas-showing-how-words-are-organised-neuroscience</link>
      <description><p>Using brain imaging, scientists have built a map displaying how words and their meanings are represented across different regions of the brain</p><p>Scientists have created an “atlas of the brain” that reveals how the meanings of words are arranged across different regions of the organ.</p><p>Like a colourful quilt laid over the cortex, the atlas displays in rainbow hues how individual words and the concepts they convey can be grouped together in clumps of white matter.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/apr/27/brain-atlas-showing-how-words-are-organised-neuroscience">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>LSD's impact on the brain revealed in groundbreaking images</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/apr/11/lsd-impact-brain-revealed-groundbreaking-images</link>
      <description><p>First modern scans of people high on psychedelic drug has given researchers unprecedented insight into neural basis for its effects </p><p>The profound impact of LSD on the brain has been laid bare by the first modern scans of people high on the drug.</p><p>The images, taken from volunteers who agreed to take a trip in the name of science, have given researchers an unprecedented insight into the neural basis for effects produced by one of the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/shortcuts/2015/nov/29/silicon-valley-techies-dropping-lsd-at-work">most powerful drugs ever created</a>.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/apr/11/lsd-impact-brain-revealed-groundbreaking-images">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Battered pot found in Cornish garage unlocks Egypt excavation secrets</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/may/26/pot-found-cornwall-garage-reveals-egypt-excavation-history</link>
      <description>Pot sheds light on the work of archeologist Flinders Petrie whose finds scattered across the world in the late 19th century<br /><p>A battered pot found in a garage in Cornwall, broken in antiquity and broken again and mended with superglue some 5,500 years later, was treasure – but the scruffy little cardboard label it held is now unlocking a lost history of finds from excavations in Egypt scattered across the world in the late 19th century.</p><p>The pot came with an odd family legend that back in the 1950s it was accepted in lieu of a fare by a taxi driver in High Wycombe. Alice Stevenson, curator at <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/museums/petrie" title="">the Petrie Museum in London</a>, which among its 80,000 objects has the original excavation records and hundreds of pieces from the same Egyptian cemetery, believes the story is true and may even have identified the mysterious passenger.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/may/26/pot-found-cornwall-garage-reveals-egypt-excavation-history">Continue reading...</a></description>
